data.text:
For touring on paved roads yes. But if you say rode trails then yes. I host Arizona Trail hikers. But last spring I had a guy stay that rode the trail from Mexico to here on a full suspension mountain bike. It's a often grueling 600 miles. The entire AZT is 800 miles Mexico border to Utah border. But part crosses the Grand Canyon and bikes aren't allowed in it. In September I'm buying a REI brand Ghost-square-cross-1.8-bike to begin my next bike tour on. It has 27 gears and a front suspension fork. https://www.rei.com/product/125926/ghost-square-cross-18-bike My Raliegh fat bike above with the yellow panniers is a heavy 50 lb solid steel, no suspension bike. I have just a non-mechanical shock seat post on it. I've ridden it about 25,000 miles since I bought it in August 2019 on 3 tours.

data.text: Sick as a dog in a nasty town in central CA. Was so sick that I could only bike 10 miles the next day, very close to pneumonia. I couldn‚Äôt find a spot in that nasty town so I slept in a sleeping bag on an air pad on a footprint in the back of what was a school. The guy opening the gate the next morning was startled to find me, but I showed him the bike and my gear and he understood immediately but did tell me that the teachers would be arriving in 10-15 minutes and that I should leave before they get here. Then I rode ten miles before day camping behind a gas station for the only slice of shade I could find for a terrible 5-hr attempt at napping by the 101 highway. Those were terrible days.

data.text: 2nd night of our world tour. Set up our tent off route 1 in Lincolnshire UK, in a field, no crops, well away from the road. Just settled in for the night when we heard a car coming towards us. It pulled past us then reversed. My ever so brave husband sent me out. It was the farmer whose field we were in, just checking we were OK. Phew!
data.author: Debs Mutton

data.text: It was four of us, in our late teens, about 36 years ago. Our parents let us cycle 350 miles from Chicago to Rhinelander Wisconsin to summer scout camp. We did it three years in a row. 350 miles in 3.5 days, with all camping gear. We‚Äôd slip into the forest around six pm on the edge of the road in rural Wisconsin. The highlight was once spotting a bunch of big appliance boxes at the back of some business at the edge of a small town. Late and tired of pitching our two tents, we assembled an abode from boxes and put together a makeshift bike garage. Turned out to be more work then pitching two tents, but this was certainly more memorable. The things you can get away with in your youth! üòÜ
